Install monitoring systems with sensors designed to detect specific contaminants.
Follow CIBSE AM10, Section 4, to predict that room-by-room airflows will provide effective natural ventilation.

scoring_criteria.criteria: The project achieves both Option 1 and Option 2, meeting all specified requirements.
The project achieves either Option 1 or Option 2, meeting all specified requirements.
The project does not meet the requirements under either option.

INDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (EQ).name: Low-Emitting Materials
INDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (EQ).intent: To reduce concentrations of chemical contaminants that can damage air quality, human health, productivity, and the environment.

general: This credit covers VOC emissions in the indoor air and the VOC content of materials, as well as the testing methods by which indoor VOC emissions are determined.
Different materials must meet different requirements to be considered compliant for this credit.
The building interior and exterior are organized in seven categories, each with different thresholds of compliance.

requirements: Achieve the threshold level of compliance with emissions and content standards for the number of product categories listed.
Table 1 outlines thresholds of compliance for 7 categories of materials.
Table 2 shows points awarded based on the number of compliant categories.
If some products in a category do not meet the criteria, use the budget calculation method.
Points are awarded based on the percentage of total compliance (Table 3).

The budget method organizes the building interior into six assemblies: flooring, ceilings, walls, thermal and acoustic insulation, furniture, and for Healthcare and Schools, exterior applied products.
Determine the total percentage of compliant materials using provided equations.

emissions_and_content_requirements: Products must meet specific requirements based on their category.
Inherently nonemitting sources are considered fully compliant without VOC emissions testing.
General emissions evaluation must be conducted per CDPH Standard Method v1.1–2010.
Wet-applied products have additional VOC content requirements.
Composite wood must meet CARB requirements for ultra-low-emitting formaldehyde (ULEF) resins or no added formaldehyde resins.
New furniture must be tested per ANSI/BIFMA standards.
healthcare_and_schools: Batt insulation products may contain no added formaldehyde.
Exterior applied products must meet specific VOC limits.
Hot-mopped asphalt and coal tar sealants are prohibited.

scoring_criteria.criteria: The project meets the highest compliance threshold under Option 1 or Option 2, achieving maximum points.
The project meets the minimum compliance threshold under Option 1 or Option 2.
The project does not meet the minimum compliance threshold under any option.

INDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (EQ).name: Construction Indoor Air Quality Management Plan
INDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (EQ).intent: To promote the well-being of construction workers and building occupants by minimizing indoor air quality problems associated with construction and renovation.

general: Develop and implement an indoor air quality (IAQ) management plan for the construction and preoccupancy phases of the building.
Meet or exceed all applicable recommended control measures of the SMACNA IAQ Guidelines for Occupied Buildings under Construction, 2nd edition, 2007.
Protect absorptive materials stored on-site and installed from moisture damage.
Do not operate permanently installed air-handling equipment during construction unless specified filtration media are installed.
Replace all filtration media immediately before occupancy.
Prohibit the use of tobacco products inside the building and within 25 feet (7.5 meters) of the building entrance during construction.

additional_requirements: Develop and implement a moisture control plan.
Schedule construction procedures to minimize exposure of absorbent materials to VOC emissions.
Develop a plan to manage fumes from outdoor activities generating high VOC emissions.
Develop a plan to reduce noise emissions and vibrations from construction equipment.
Establish an integrative infection control team to evaluate infection control risk and document required precautions.

scoring_criteria.criteria: The project develops and implements a comprehensive IAQ management plan meeting all specified requirements.
The project fails to develop an IAQ management plan or does not meet the specified requirements.

INDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (EQ).name: Indoor Air Quality Assessment
INDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (EQ).intent: To establish better quality indoor air in the building after construction and during occupancy.

requirements: Install new filtration media and perform a building flush-out by supplying a total air volume of 14,000 cubic feet of outdoor air per square foot.
Maintain an internal temperature of at least 60°F and no higher than 80°F and relative humidity no higher than 60%.
If occupancy is desired before the flush-out is completed, specific conditions must be met (Path 2).
Conduct baseline IAQ testing using protocols consistent with specified methods for all occupied spaces.
Demonstrate that contaminants do not exceed the concentration levels listed in Table 1.
Conduct measurements before occupancy but during normal occupied hours.
For any noncompliant contaminants, take corrective action and retest.

scoring_criteria.criteria: The project successfully completes Option 2, meeting all testing requirements and contaminant thresholds.
The project successfully completes Option 1, meeting all flush-out requirements.
The project does not meet the requirements under either option.

INDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (EQ).name: Thermal Comfort
INDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (EQ).intent: To promote occupants’ productivity, comfort, and well-being by providing quality thermal comfort.

requirements: Design HVAC systems and the building envelope to meet the requirements of ASHRAE Standard 55–2010.
For natatoriums, demonstrate compliance with ASHRAE HVAC Applications Handbook, Chapter 5.
Design HVAC systems and the building envelope to meet the requirements of ISO 7730:2005 and CEN Standard EN 15251:2007.
Provide individual thermal comfort controls for at least 50% of individual occupant spaces.
Provide group thermal comfort controls for all shared multioccupant spaces.
Thermal comfort controls must allow adjustment of at least one of the following: air temperature, radiant temperature, air speed, and humidity.

project_type_specific.hospitality: Guest rooms are assumed to provide adequate thermal comfort controls and are not included in the credit calculations.
project_type_specific.retail: Meet the above requirements for at least 50% of individual occupant spaces in office and administrative areas.
project_type_specific.healthcare: Provide individual thermal comfort controls for every patient room and at least 50% of the remaining individual occupant spaces.

scoring_criteria.criteria: The project meets all requirements for thermal comfort design and control.
The project fails to meet one or more of the specified thermal comfort requirements.

Innovation (IN).name: Innovation
Innovation (IN).intent: To encourage projects to achieve exceptional or innovative performance.

general: Project teams can use any combination of innovation, pilot, and exemplary performance strategies.

requirements: Achieve significant, measurable environmental performance using a strategy not addressed in the LEED green building rating system.
Identify the following for each innovation credit attempted:
- The intent of the proposed innovation credit.
- Proposed requirements for compliance.
- Proposed submittals to demonstrate compliance.
- The design approach or strategies used to meet the requirements.
Achieve one or more pilot credits from USGBC’s LEED Pilot Credit Library.

strategies.name: Innovation
requirements: Defined in Option 1 above.

strategies.name: Pilot
requirements: Defined in Option 2 above.

strategies.name: Exemplary Performance
requirements: Achieve exemplary performance in an existing LEED v4 prerequisite or credit that allows exemplary performance, as specified in the LEED Reference Guide, v4 edition.
An exemplary performance point is typically earned for achieving double the credit requirements or the next incremental percentage threshold.

scoring_criteria.criteria: Points are awarded based on the number of innovative strategies, pilot credits, and exemplary performance achievements. Each distinct strategy earns 1 point, up to a maximum of 5 points.
The project does not successfully implement any qualifying innovation, pilot, or exemplary performance strategies.

Innovation (IN).name: LEED Accredited Professional
Innovation (IN).intent: To encourage the team integration required by a LEED project and to streamline the application and certification process.
requirements: At least one principal participant of the project team must be a LEED Accredited Professional (AP) with a specialty appropriate for the project.

scoring_criteria.criteria: The project team includes at least one LEED AP with a specialty appropriate for the project.
The project team does not include a LEED AP with an appropriate specialty.

Regional Priority (RP).name: Regional Priority
Regional Priority (RP).intent: To provide an incentive for the achievement of credits that address geographically specific environmental, social equity, and public health priorities.

general: Earn up to four of the six Regional Priority credits.
These credits have been identified by the USGBC regional councils and chapters as having additional regional importance for the project’s region.
A database of Regional Priority credits and their geographic applicability is available on the USGBC website: http://www.usgbc.org.
One point is awarded for each Regional Priority credit achieved, up to a maximum of four.

scoring_criteria.criteria: One point is awarded for each Regional Priority credit achieved by the project, up to a maximum of 4 points.
The project does not achieve any Regional Priority credits.
